body.directions: Listen to the audio, then complete the multiple choice questions that follow.

body.quiz: Which of the following is most likely to be found together with the item in the audio on a dining table?
body.correct: Excellently done! 刀子 dāozi means “knife,” and it can usually be seen together with a fork.
body.incorrect: Not quite. Listen to the audio again, and think about its meaning. You got this!

body.quiz: Which of the following can the item in the audio be used for?
body.answer: Image of a bowl of soup ©Shutterstock
options: Image of loaf of bread on chopping board, close-up ©Shutterstock
Image of Close-up of grilled meat on plate©Shutterstock
up of two apples with white background ©Shutterstock
body.correct: Fabulous job! 勺子 sháozi (spoon) can be used to scoop up soup, but it is not very useful for cutting a steak.
body.incorrect: So close! Listen again and try to understand the meaning of the word in the audio, and then consider how it can be used for the items in the options.

body.quiz: Which of the following items will you find the utensil in the audio useful for?
body.correct: Outstanding job! 筷子 kuàizi (chopsticks) are a common utensil used for Chinese food. You can easily find them in any Chinese or Asian restaurant.
body.incorrect: Not quite… think about the meaning of the word in the audio and what it is most likely used for.

body.textVersion: Audio for 玻璃杯 bōlí bēi

body.quiz: Which of the following is the item in the audio least likely used for?
body.answer: Audio for 咖啡 kāfēi
options: Audio for 牛奶 niúnǎi
Audio for 苏打 sūdǎ
Audio for 果汁 guǒzhī
body.correct: Excellently done! 玻璃杯 bōlí bēi (glass) is perfect for holding cold liquids but maybe not a good idea to have a hot cup of coffee in a glass. You could burn your hand!
body.incorrect: Very close… listen again and think about the meaning of the word. What type of drink can it be the least useful for?

body.quiz: Which of the following best describes the item in the audio?
body.answer: You need it when you spill your drink.
options: It is used to pick up food.
It is made of metal or stone.
You need it when you order food.
body.correct: Awesome job! 餐巾 cānjīn (napkin) comes handy when you spill a drink, but you might not need it when you order food.
body.incorrect: Not quite. Listen again to understand its meaning, and then think about situations when it can be used.
